what: Grace Rade, Maeve Tyler-Penny, Julia Ting
title: actLifer
text: actLifer package contains functions create actuarial life tables three datasets ready made life table. mathematical step transforming mortality data life expectancy corresponding function, builds table step. datasets prepared ready use functions.
code: library(actLifer) #> Loading required package: dplyr #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

title: actLifer
text: Mathematically speaking, mortality data first step calculating life expectancy. several intermediate calculations number deaths given age life expectancy, step builds previous values. mind, created several functions calculated intermediate value build complete actuarial lifetable combined. Lifetables can rather easily created spreadsheet, rather involved process R. functions simplify procedure creating lifetable one function option group different categorical variables. actLifer package useful tool anyone works mortality data, wants calculate life expectancy, wants find intermediate values number deaths life expectancy.

title: actLifer
text: functions take dataset columns age group (\(x\)), deaths age (\(D_x\)), midyear population age (\(P_x\)). central_death_rate(): Calculates central/crude death rate, \(M_x\), number deaths given period divided population risk given period. Formula: \(M_x = \frac{D_x}{P_x}\) optional column life table, can useful ascertain general indication health status given area population. conditional_death_prob(): Calculates conditional probability death age (\(q_x\)), probability dying certain age within given period. Formula: \(q_x = \frac{D_x}{P_x + \frac{D_x}{2}}\) conditional_life_prob(): Calculates conditional prbability life age (\(p_x\)), probability living certain age within given period. Formula: \(p_x = 1 - q_x\) please note R round conditional probability life 1, present problems later calculations number_to_survive(): Calculates number people survive given age interval (\(l_x\)), starting arbitrary number 100,000 age 0 (age < 1). Formula: \(l_x = l_{x-1} \cdot p_{x-1}; l_0 = 100,000\) prop_to_survive(): Calculates proportion population surviving age \(x\). Formula: \(l_x/100000\) another optional column life table, can removed calculations completed. person_years(): Calculates person years lived age (), total number years lived age \(x\) people survive age. Formula: $ L_x = $ total_years_lived(): Calculates total years lived age \(x\), sum person years \(0\) age \(x\). Formula: \(T_x = \sum_{= 0}^{x}L_x\) life_expectancy(): Calculates life expectancy age \(x\) (\(e_x\)), number years average person expected live beyond current age. Formula: \(e_x = \frac{T_x}{l_x}\) function output complete life table, without added customization lifetable() function. lifetable(): Outputs complete lifetable ability customize optional columns included, add extra grouping variables. includeAllSteps = TRUE, lifetable include CentralDeathRate PropToSurvive final output includeCDR = FALSE, CentralDeathRate included final output includePS = FALSE, PropToSurvive included dataset includeAllSteps, includeCDR, includePS TRUE default Calculating life extpectancy iterative process, building previous intermediate calculations. functions call function previous step executes, meaning output dataset include columns previous steps. reason, need run step individually dataset, simply run function last step trying complete. Central Death Rate optional column dataset must called addition functions.
code: example <- lifetable(mortality2, "age_group", "population", "deaths") #> # A tibble: 5 × 11 #>   age_group deaths population CentralDeathRate ConditionalProbDeath #>   <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>                <dbl> #> 1 < 1 year   23161    3970145         0.00583              0.00582  #> 2 1 year      1568    3995008         0.000392             0.000392 #> 3 2 years     1046    3992154         0.000262             0.000262 #> 4 3 years      791    3982074         0.000199             0.000199 #> 5 4 years      640    3987656         0.000160             0.000160 #> # ℹ 6 more variables: ConditionalProbLife <dbl>, NumberToSurvive <dbl>, #> #   PropToSurvive <dbl>, PersonYears <dbl>, TotalYears <dbl>, #> #   LifeExpectancy <dbl>

title: actLifer
text: package includes three datasets, sourced CDC Wonder Database (https://wonder.cdc.gov/ucd-icd10.html). mortality contains data year 2018 single-year age groups mortality2 contains data year 2016 single-year age gaps mortality3 contains data year 2016 single-year age gaps gender grouping variable

what: What Do These Datasets Look Like?
title: actLifer
text: included data sets include age group variable, population variable, deaths variable. Population represents mid-year population age group. Deaths represents number people age group died. ’s first five rows mortality2 look like.
code: #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   age_group deaths population #>   <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 < 1 year   23161    3970145 #> 2 1 year      1568    3995008 #> 3 2 years     1046    3992154 #> 4 3 years      791    3982074 #> 5 4 years      640    3987656

title: actLifer
text: package can used researchers, actuaries, anyone working mortality data. can particularly useful wanting calculate life expectancy specific groups, life expectancy data sub-groups total population given area difficult find. Additionally, package can used compare life expectancy different points time, COVID-19 pandemic.

what: What Can We Do With This Data?
title: actLifer
text: can use package address question : life expectancy differ population groups? specific age-range life expectancy dramatically changes? central death rate significantly differ probability death certain age? many !

previous_headings: What Can We Do With This Data?
title: actLifer
text: life expectancy differ population groups? built-dataset mortality3 provides gender variable can used group data. lifetable function allows extra grouping arguments, function use. Please note gender variable name CDC uses mean biological sex (Male, Female) output tibble data frame calculated life expectancy gender. can see differences life expectancy males females. Users can use many extra grouping variables get even specific population subgroups. suggested variables include (limited ) state/geographic area, race, sex, income group, health status.
code: lifetable(mortality3, "age_group", "population", "deaths", FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, "gender") #> # A tibble: 170 × 6 #> # Groups:   "gender" [1] #>    age_group gender deaths population `"gender"` LifeExpectancy #>    <chr>     <chr>   <dbl>      <dbl> <chr>               <dbl> #>  1 < 1 year  Female  10294    1939667 gender               139. #>  2 < 1 year  Male    12867    2030478 gender               138. #>  3 1 year    Female    694    1953850 gender               138. #>  4 1 year    Male      874    2041158 gender               137. #>  5 2 years   Female    474    1949132 gender               136. #>  6 2 years   Male      572    2043022 gender               135. #>  7 3 years   Female    323    1947408 gender               134. #>  8 3 years   Male      468    2034666 gender               133. #>  9 4 years   Female    298    1950127 gender               132. #> 10 4 years   Male      342    2037529 gender               131. #> # ℹ 160 more rows

previous_headings: What Can We Do With This Data?
title: actLifer
text: specific age-range life expectancy dramatically changes? mortality dataset age grouped single-year intervals. can use dataset see life expectancy changes dramatically one interval next. abbreviated output, can see life expectancy change dramatically year year.
code: lifetable(mortality2, "age_group", "population", "deaths", TRUE, FALSE, FALSE) #> # A tibble: 85 × 9 #>    age_group deaths population ConditionalProbDeath ConditionalProbLife #>    <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>                <dbl>               <dbl> #>  1 < 1 year   23161    3970145             0.00582                0.994 #>  2 1 year      1568    3995008             0.000392               1.00  #>  3 2 years     1046    3992154             0.000262               1.00  #>  4 3 years      791    3982074             0.000199               1.00  #>  5 4 years      640    3987656             0.000160               1.00  #>  6 5 years      546    4032515             0.000135               1.00  #>  7 6 years      488    4029655             0.000121               1.00  #>  8 7 years      511    4029991             0.000127               1.00  #>  9 8 years      483    4159114             0.000116               1.00  #> 10 9 years      462    4178524             0.000111               1.00  #> # ℹ 75 more rows #> # ℹ 4 more variables: NumberToSurvive <dbl>, PersonYears <dbl>, #> #   TotalYears <dbl>, LifeExpectancy <dbl>

previous_headings: What Can We Do With This Data?
title: actLifer
text: central death rate significantly differ probability death certain age? Central Death Rate (also known Crude Death Mortality Rate), necessary intermediate step calculating life expectancy, conditional_death_prop() function call central_death_rate(). compare two measures, run functions. Central Death Rate Conditional Probability Death start similar value, can see first five rows mort. However, one ages, difference Central Death Rate Conditional Probability Death becomes larger, can see last five rows dataset.
code: mort<- mortality2 %>%    central_death_rate("age_group", "population", "deaths") %>%    conditional_death_prob("age_group", "population", "deaths")  head(mort) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   age_group deaths population CentralDeathRate ConditionalProbDeath #>   <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>                <dbl> #> 1 < 1 year   23161    3970145         0.00583              0.00582  #> 2 1 year      1568    3995008         0.000392             0.000392 #> 3 2 years     1046    3992154         0.000262             0.000262 #> 4 3 years      791    3982074         0.000199             0.000199 #> 5 4 years      640    3987656         0.000160             0.000160 #> 6 5 years      546    4032515         0.000135             0.000135 tail(mort) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   age_group deaths population CentralDeathRate ConditionalProbDeath #>   <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>                <dbl> #> 1 79 years   62081    1439937           0.0431               0.0422 #> 2 80 years   64987    1358260           0.0478               0.0467 #> 3 81 years   67240    1284298           0.0524               0.0510 #> 4 82 years   67120    1135109           0.0591               0.0574 #> 5 83 years   69758    1079082           0.0646               0.0626 #> 6 84 years   72916    1008890           0.0723               0.0698

title: Creating Actuarial Life Tables
text: actLifer package contains functions create life table based mortality data, ultimately calculates life expectancy data annual deaths given ages/age groups. package also contains mortality data CDC wonder. package useful actuaries, epidemiologists, data scientists working mortality data.

title: Creating Actuarial Life Tables
text: can install development version actLifer GitHub : can install reslease version actLifer CRAN :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("g-rade/actLifer") #install.packages("actLifer")

title: Creating Actuarial Life Tables
code: library(actLifer) #> Loading required package: dplyr #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  ## Take a look at the mortality2 data fram head(mortality2) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   age_group deaths population #>   <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 < 1 year   23161    3970145 #> 2 1 year      1568    3995008 #> 3 2 years     1046    3992154 #> 4 3 years      791    3982074 #> 5 4 years      640    3987656 #> 6 5 years      546    4032515  ## Use the lifetable function to make a custom life table with just ## CentralDeathRate, PropToSurvive, and LifeExpectancy by setting includeAllSteps = FALSE  lifetable(mortality2, "age_group", "population", "deaths", FALSE, TRUE, TRUE) #> # A tibble: 85 × 6 #>    age_group deaths population CentralDeathRate PropToSurvive LifeExpectancy #>    <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>         <dbl>          <dbl> #>  1 < 1 year   23161    3970145         0.00583          1               75.9 #>  2 1 year      1568    3995008         0.000392         0.994           75.3 #>  3 2 years     1046    3992154         0.000262         0.994           74.4 #>  4 3 years      791    3982074         0.000199         0.994           73.4 #>  5 4 years      640    3987656         0.000160         0.993           72.4 #>  6 5 years      546    4032515         0.000135         0.993           71.4 #>  7 6 years      488    4029655         0.000121         0.993           70.4 #>  8 7 years      511    4029991         0.000127         0.993           69.4 #>  9 8 years      483    4159114         0.000116         0.993           68.4 #> 10 9 years      462    4178524         0.000111         0.993           67.4 #> # ℹ 75 more rows   ## Or show everything by setting includeAllSteps=TRUE, includeCDR=TRUE, and includePS=TRUE which are the default values lifetable(mortality2, "age_group", "population", "deaths") #> # A tibble: 85 × 11 #>    age_group deaths population CentralDeathRate ConditionalProbDeath #>    <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>                <dbl> #>  1 < 1 year   23161    3970145         0.00583              0.00582  #>  2 1 year      1568    3995008         0.000392             0.000392 #>  3 2 years     1046    3992154         0.000262             0.000262 #>  4 3 years      791    3982074         0.000199             0.000199 #>  5 4 years      640    3987656         0.000160             0.000160 #>  6 5 years      546    4032515         0.000135             0.000135 #>  7 6 years      488    4029655         0.000121             0.000121 #>  8 7 years      511    4029991         0.000127             0.000127 #>  9 8 years      483    4159114         0.000116             0.000116 #> 10 9 years      462    4178524         0.000111             0.000111 #> # ℹ 75 more rows #> # ℹ 6 more variables: ConditionalProbLife <dbl>, NumberToSurvive <dbl>, #> #   PropToSurvive <dbl>, PersonYears <dbl>, TotalYears <dbl>, #> #   LifeExpectancy <dbl>

what: Conditional Probability of Survival at Age x — conditional_life_prob
title: Conditional Probability of Survival at Age x — conditional_life_prob
text: Adds new column called ConditionalProbLife dataset input. ConditionalProbLife column contains probabilities surviving given age group. words, probability someone surviving next birthday.

title: Conditional Probability of Survival at Age x — conditional_life_prob
code: conditional_life_prob(data, age, pop, deaths)

title: Conditional Probability of Survival at Age x — conditional_life_prob
text: data mortality dataset, includes age grouping variable age age grouping variable, must cateogrical pop Population age group, must numeric deaths number deaths age group, must numeric

title: Conditional Probability of Survival at Age x — conditional_life_prob
text: Dataset input added columns ConditionalProbDeath ConditionalProbLife. words, "steps" conditional probability survival.

title: Conditional Probability of Survival at Age x — conditional_life_prob

what: Life Expectancy of Age x — life_expectancy

code: life_expectancy(data, age, pop, deaths)

title: Life Expectancy of Age x — life_expectancy
text: data mortality dataset, includes age grouping variable, age age grouping variable, must categorical pop Population age group, must numeric deaths midyear number deaths age group, must numeric

title: Life Expectancy of Age x — life_expectancy
text: Dataset input added columns: ConditionalProbDeath, ConditionalProbLife, NumberToSurvive, PersonYears, TotalYears, LifeExpectancy.

title: Life Expectancy of Age x — life_expectancy
code: # This function will add the ConditionalProbDeath, ConditionalProbLife, # NumberToSurvive, PropToSurvive, PersonYears, TotalYears, and LifeExpectancy # columns to the dataset. # This will be a full lifetable life_expectancy(mortality2, "age_group", "population", "deaths") #> # A tibble: 85 × 10 #>    age_group deaths population ConditionalProbDeath ConditionalProbLife #>    <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>                <dbl>               <dbl> #>  1 < 1 year   23161    3970145             0.00582                0.994 #>  2 1 year      1568    3995008             0.000392               1.00  #>  3 2 years     1046    3992154             0.000262               1.00  #>  4 3 years      791    3982074             0.000199               1.00  #>  5 4 years      640    3987656             0.000160               1.00  #>  6 5 years      546    4032515             0.000135               1.00  #>  7 6 years      488    4029655             0.000121               1.00  #>  8 7 years      511    4029991             0.000127               1.00  #>  9 8 years      483    4159114             0.000116               1.00  #> 10 9 years      462    4178524             0.000111               1.00  #> # ℹ 75 more rows #> # ℹ 5 more variables: NumberToSurvive <dbl>, PropToSurvive <dbl>, #> #   PersonYears <dbl>, TotalYears <dbl>, LifeExpectancy <dbl>

title: Lifetable Function — lifetable
text: Gives user control lifetable compared life_expectancy() function. Allows user add central death rate proportion surviving age x. Allows user omit accessory columns used calculate life expectancy.

title: Lifetable Function — lifetable
code: lifetable(   data,   age,   pop,   deaths,   includeAllSteps = TRUE,   includeCDR = TRUE,   includePS = TRUE,   ... )

title: Lifetable Function — lifetable
text: data mortality dataset, includes age grouping variable, age age grouping variable, must categorical pop Population age group, must numeric deaths midyear number deaths age group, must numeric includeAllSteps false, include proportion surviving age x life expectancy age x includeCDR true, include central death rate age group includePS true, include proportion surviving age group ... optional grouping variables (can race, gender, etc.)

title: Lifetable Function — lifetable
text: Lifetable

title: Lifetable Function — lifetable
code: # Running lifetable() and choosing not to include CentralDeathRate and # ProportionToSurvive (optional columns) in the output dataset  lifetable(mortality2, "age_group", "population", "deaths", FALSE, TRUE, TRUE) #> # A tibble: 85 × 6 #>    age_group deaths population CentralDeathRate PropToSurvive LifeExpectancy #>    <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>         <dbl>          <dbl> #>  1 < 1 year   23161    3970145         0.00583          1               75.9 #>  2 1 year      1568    3995008         0.000392         0.994           75.3 #>  3 2 years     1046    3992154         0.000262         0.994           74.4 #>  4 3 years      791    3982074         0.000199         0.994           73.4 #>  5 4 years      640    3987656         0.000160         0.993           72.4 #>  6 5 years      546    4032515         0.000135         0.993           71.4 #>  7 6 years      488    4029655         0.000121         0.993           70.4 #>  8 7 years      511    4029991         0.000127         0.993           69.4 #>  9 8 years      483    4159114         0.000116         0.993           68.4 #> 10 9 years      462    4178524         0.000111         0.993           67.4 #> # ℹ 75 more rows

what: The Number of People to Survive to Age x — number_to_survive
title: The Number of People to Survive to Age x — number_to_survive
text: Adds new column called NumberToSurvive dataset input. NumberToSurvive represents number people living beginning given age interval, using arbitrary 100,000 people first age group table.

code: number_to_survive(data, age, pop, deaths)

title: The Number of People to Survive to Age x — number_to_survive
text: data mortality dataset, includes age grouping variable, age age grouping variable, must categorical pop Population age group, must numeric deaths midyear number deaths age group, must numeric

title: The Number of People to Survive to Age x — number_to_survive
